question:
(a) What is Credit?

(b) Explain three ways by which banks grant credit to customers.

(c) Give two advantages and three disadvantages of credit sales.
answer:
(a) The granting of permission to pay at a future date for something of value received now is called credit. It is defined as the granting of the use of possession of goods and services without immediately paying for them.

(b) Three ways by which banks grant credit to customers are:

(i) Loan: Banks can give loans to their customers for a short period which includes interest charges. It is usual for banks to require collateral security before they can give loans. Collateral securities are assets which can be converted to cash upon default by customers.

(ii) Overdraft: An overdraft is a facility granted to a customer who operates a current account. This enables him to draw cheques to an agreed maximum over the amount outstanding to his credit in his current account. For example, if he has #600 in his account, he may withdraw #1000. Banks charge interest on overdraft.

(iii) Discounting bills of exchange: Commercial banks discount bills of exchange, that is, they pay cash for bills of exchange before the bills mature.

(c) Advantages of Credit Sales are:

(i) Credit sales enables many firms to meet temporary needs for cash.

(ii) Credit sales brings higher profit.

(iii) There is increase in sales or turnover.

(iv) It reduces the risk of holding stock.

(v) Credit sales makes it possible for consumers to have immediate possession of the goods and services they need even though they do not pay at once.

Disadvantages of Credit Sales are:

(i) Credit customers pay higher than cash customers.

(ii) There is risk of non -payment by the customers.

(iii) The credit customer may be tempted to buy more than what he can afford.

(iv) Credit sales involve a lot of book keeping processes.

question:
(a) Who is an agent?

(b) Give six duties of an agent.

(c) State three rights of an agent.
answer:
(a) An agent; is a person who effects a contract between his principal and a third party. The agent may be an employee of his principal, e.g. salesman in a shop or he may be an independent contractor. He has power to make a binding contract between the principal and third parties without himself becoming a party to the contract.

(b) Duties of an agent are:

(i) The agent must keep proper book of accounts of all transactions connected with the agency and render them to the principal on request.

(ii) He must not delegate the performance of his duties.

(iii) He must not misuse confidential information regarding his principal's affairs.

(iv) He must not make secret profit or accept bribes in respect of the agency.

(v) He must not compete or let his interest conflict with that of his principal.

(vi) He must exercise due care and skill in the performance of his duty.

(vii) The agent must carry out the principal's lawful instructions.

(c) Rights of an agent are:

(i) The agent has right to his remuneration.

(ii) He has right to be indemnified against loss arising in the performance of his duty.

(iii) He has right to be paid any expense incurred in the course of the business.

question:
(a) What is production?

(b) Explain the different activities involved in industrial, commercial and service occupations.
answer:
(a) Production; is the transformation of raw materials into finished goods and distribution to the final consumers to satisfy their wants. It involves the making of goods and services available to satisfy human wants. Production can also be defined as the creation of utility.

(b) The different activities involved in industrial, commercial and services occupations are:

Industrial occupation: These are concerned with obtaining the raw materials and changing them into finished goods. Industry is usually divided into three groups namely extractive, manufacturing and constructive industries.

(i) Extractive industry is basically concerned with the production of food items for immediate consumption and raw materials to feed the manufacturing industries.

(ii) Manufacturing industry; is engaged in utilizing the products of the extractive industry to produce finished goods like shoes, clothes, books, etc.

(iii) Constructive industry; engages in the building of roads, bridges, houses etc out of finished products like cement, iron rods, etc. Commercial occupation: They are concerned with the act of buying and selling of goods and services which directly or indirectly assist trade. These services (i.e transport, warehousing, banking, insurance, advertising etc) are sometimes referred to as aids to trade.

These are:
(i) Advertising brings the existence of the goods to the awareness of the consumer.

(ii) Banking provides credit facilities for the purchase and payment of goods.

(iii) Transportation ensures the movement of traders, goods and services from one place to another by land, air and sea.

(iv) Warehousing helps in storing and preserving the goods until they are needed.

(v) Insurance aids trade by spreading the risks which the trader would otherwise face alone. Service occupation: They render personal and direct services to people who pay for such services. Their efforts constitute services that are salable to consumers who pay for them directly or indirectly. It can be divided into direct and indirect services.

(i) Direct services; are rendered directly to those who employ them and pay for them directly, e.g housemaids.

(ii) Indirect services; are usually not paid for by members of the public directly but by the government out of the taxes realised from them. Those in this category are policemen, soldiers, etc.

question:
(a) What is transportation by pipeline?

(b) Explain any four advantages and four disadvantages of transportation by pipeline.
answer:
(a) Pipeline transportation: Pipelines are used mostly for the transportation of liquids and gases. Pipelines are built both on the surface and underground. For example, crude oil is transported from Port Harcourt to Kaduna. Pipelines can also be used to carry water to homes.

(b) Advantages of Pipeline transportation are:

(i) The operating or maintenance ost is low.

(ii) Pipeline reduces road congestion and accidents.

(iii) Pipeline is a safe means of transporting liquids.

iv) No physical labour or activity is required to move the goods through pipes.

(v) Pipeline is less vulnerable to climatic damage.

Disadvantages of Pipeline transportation are:

(i) The cost of constructing pipelines is high.

(ii) Pipeline transportation lends itself to bunkering and tampering.

(iii) If damage is not discovered early, a lot of wastage will occur.

(iv) it takes a lot of land space.

(v) Pipeline can easily be destroyed when there is road construction.

(vi) It cannot carry other goods except liquid only.

b)(i) Order cheque; is a cheque made payable to a person named on it or his order. What this means is that an order Cheque is only paid to the person whose name appears on it or another person to whom he will authorise the bank to pay the money to by endorsing the cheque to be paid to the person. By endorsing an order cheque, it becomes a bearer cheque, which anybody can present for payment.

(ii) Bearer cheque; is a cheque that is made payable to whoever presents it and that is the meaning of word bearer. It does not mean that no name is written on the cheque. (iv) Non-Negotiable cheque; is a cheque carrying a warning to whoever that is accepting it that he has no better right to it than the transferee. The words do not imply that the cheque cannot be endorsed to a third party.

question: Explain five ways by which NITEL has contributed to the success of business in Nigeria.
answer:
Ways by which NITEL has contributed to the success of business in Nigeria are:

(I) NITEL helps firms to transact business through telephone services.

(ii) Firms also benefit from telegraph and telex services.

(iii) It provides fax services / exact copy of documents.

(iv) Live telecast services is provided by NITEL.

(v) Firms can also send their telegram through NITEL.

(vi) NITEL also renders data transmission service. This is a means whereby business units can transmit digital data by computers.

question:
(a) What is personal selling?

(b) Explain four reasons why firms engage in personal selling.
answer:
(a) Personal selling; is a direct, face-to-face or person-to-person communication with the customer. A personnel of the firm comes into contact with the customer and shows the customer how to use the product. The salesperson must be courteous, tactful and have a clear knowledge of the product being marketed.

(b) Reasons why firms engage in personal selling are:

(i) It allows the sales person to foresee a customer's particular needs and problems.

(ii) It makes it possible for immediate feedback from the customers.

(iii) It is also an important public relations tool utilized by firms to project their image.

(iv) It is good when a new product is to be introduced.

(v) It is also used by firms that sell technical goods requiring installation and demonstration on how to use such technical product.

(vi) Personal selling provides the firm the opportunity to obtain firm orders and also sales are made on the spot.

question:
(a) Describe four obligations of the employer to the employee.

(b) State four duties of the employee to the employer.
answer:
(a) Obligations of the employer to the employees are:

(i) The employer has the duty to provide safety tools for the employee.

(ii) He is obliged to pay the employee his remuneration.

(iii) He has the obligation to provide a safe place of work.

(iv) He has the duty to train his new employees such that they can avoid reasonably foreseen able harm which could result from a failure to give them proper instructions and training.

(v) He must give the employee work to keep him busy.

(vi) The employer has a duty to reimburse his employee for any expenses or loss he incurs in the course of the employer's business.

(b) Duties of employee to the employer are:

(i) The employee must perform his duties faithfully and honestly.

(ii) He must not reveal any confidential information regarding his employer.

(iii) The employee must perform the task given to him according to laid down instructions.

(iv) The employee should be loyal.

(v) He must not allow his own interest to conflict with the interest of his employer.

(vi) The employee must show respect to his employer.

question:
(a) What is planning?

(b) Explain five advantages of delegation of authority.
answer:
(a) Planning is the setting up of targets or objective and outlining the appropriate means of achieving it. It is the process of establishing objectives for the organisation and trying to determine the best ways to accomplish them.

(b) Advantages of delegation of authority are:

(i) The work load of the supervisors will be reduced.

(ii) Delegation of authority saves a lot of time as certain duties can be delegated to the subordinates.

(iii) It makes for speed in the performance of duty.

(iv) Delegation of authority helps to train the subordinates to whom this authority is delegated to do certain jobs.

(v) Delegation of authority reduces the work load of the superior officers.
